content: woolly thoughts in pursuit of crafty mathematics squiggly things hyperbolic experiments designed by pat ashforth & steve plummer squiggly things these squiggly things have no practical use but they are very tactile objects they are fun to make and even more fun to play with they can be twisted and turned and it is very difficult to put them down once you pick them up the world expert on hyperbolic crochet is daina taimina she has written several books and papers on the topic this pattern only aims to show what happens with different rates of increase it does not explain any of the maths the pattern contains some round squiggles and some strip squiggles yarn you can use any type of yarn in any thickness you will always get a similar shape but the size of your squiggle will vary according to the thickness i used dk yarns for all the tables for each of the squiggles will give you a rough idea of how much yarn is needed hook you may need to experiment to find the best size hook to use if your work is too tight the shape will be too stiff to twist easily if it is too loose the squiggle will not hold its shape as well i used a 4 mm hook stitches i used uk double_crochet us single_crochet for all but one of my shapes you can choose to use bigger stitches if you wish these would make the squiggles more spread out and take more effort and yarn to make a compact shape making circles lie flat to make a crochet circle in uk double_crochet us single_crochet it is usual to begin with 6 stitches into a ring and then add 6 stitches on every round to many people it seems counter-intuitive that you should always add the same number of stitches however big the circle gets if you add too many stitches the surface will start to undulate if you add too few you will start to form a dish shape to make a circle in uk treble_crochet us double_crochet you usually begin with 12 stitches into the ring and add 12 stitches on every round the centres of round squiggles start as flat circles but soon start to distort because too many stitches are added starting a circle there are two ways to make the centre of a circle ○ make a short chain and join it into a loop using a slip-stitch the chain can be any length you want but 4 stitches are often enough work the starting stitches into this ring the disadvantage of this method is that it leaves a small hole in the centre of the circle ○ a magic_ring is one that you can tighten so it doesn t leave a hole you can find various descriptions of how to do this on the internet basically you form a loop of yarn over your fingers leaving a tail in any way you find
